pros: Students are held to high standards, creative and positive environment, great campus and facilities

pros: Not that hard for my major - just walking around every hour and making sure everything is in order. Sometimes doing design work here and there, but pretty simple.
cons: Sometimes a little unorganized higher up.

pros: Really great way to learn about technical problems. Great position for students

pros: Lots of resources and helpful teachers. Awesome meaning environment.

pros: Beautiful building, courteous co workers, interesting place to work.

pros: Get hands on learning with the equipment in the sound stages. You get paid to do workshops and mess around with gear. They also worked around your class schedule.
cons: No cons, really! It's really pretty great.

pros: Community, pay, and understanding of student schedules.

job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Sarasota, FL
pros: They will work with you to have flexible work hours.
cons: I would say there isn’t much cons to this position.

review_title: Not the best, not the worst
pros: For most positions, lighter workload in the summer. Each department operates fairly independently. Incredible health care benefits (for full time employees). Good PTO program (for full time employees). Beautiful campus with lots of art and creative energy.
cons: Pay is below market value. Outdated practice of keeping salaries a secret. Because departments operate independently there is sometimes a bit of lag when you need something from a different department. HR is there solely to protect the school's interests.

review_title: Good education but I feel unheard
job_title: Student Equipment Manager in Sarasota, FL
pros: very high job placement rate
cons: Whether you're a student, faculty or even a large part of the staff, being a part of the Ringling community, we often feel like our voices and opinions about how the school is run fall on deaf ears.

review_title: Thankful for my students, they made teaching worthwhile despite a stressful work environment.
pros: Creative environment. Great colleagues. Pretty campus with eager and diverse student body and mostly good weather.
cons:
- many faculty are not made to feel comfortable in questioning authority. Feeling safe and heard is luck of the draw - depending on who your department head is. 
- Human Resources - or the institution itself - have not set up a safe environment for instructors to safely communicate issues with their department head since many Faculty feel the threat of retaliation or punishment from their department heads, should we choose to complain. (The Department head in my department did not create a team environment, rather,  was allowed to create a department run by fear.) we can do an annual review of them but it seems pointless and is ineffective. 
- There is a perceived difference in how women are treated vs male colleagues - both in opportunities for advancement and in pay.

pros:
Chill Environment
Good opportunity to meet other students
cons: Payment is lower than some minimum wage jobs

review_title: Good place to live and work
pros: Benefits, good health care, great community, good vacation time
cons: Hard to level up from within

pros: Learning lots of new skills
cons: Not consistent hours, which leads to inconsistent pay

pros: Teaching at Ringling is a wonderful experience and offers an amazing quality of life.
cons: It would be nice if more elective were available to more majors and if the majors weren’t are siloed as they are. The more the students get to mix the better it is for the culture and work at the school.

pros: Ringling really took care of it's staff during the pandemic. They seemed to care about our health and well being, and Ringling's overall community is well rounded and of course, creative. Normal annual salary increase, good health care.
cons: The communication can be lacking between offices when they should be working more together for the overall sake for the school and students.

pros: Excellent, gifted surrounding faculty and administration. Fair balance between student and faculty focus. You should have time for your own work and / or family as well.
cons: Most students are excellent, but still, some can be very challenging to reach. Departments are working on higher standards of acceptance.

job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Sarasota, FL
pros: Work while working on school work.
cons: Need to manage uncooperative student.

pros: The luxury of being able to work on campus for a job.
cons: Being a student work with low pay, it's rather hard to really get through when the area is so expensive.

pros:

cons:

review_title: Good place to be a student worker
pros: Flexible hours, easy work, good boss
cons: Pay is low to average

pros: Great College Experience in Sarasota
cons: The tuition fees is very high.

pros: Love my boss, students are great to work with, flexible scheduling

pros: Working with great and talented students.
cons: There are not any cons to my job.

pros: flexible schedule, nice staff, great learning experience
cons: Ringling is a smaller college compared with other universities

pros: Faculty and staff at Ringling work as a very close knit community and are very supportive of one another and care very deeply for the student and their success. The employee benefits package and 401K match are better than most institutions which is another reflection of the caring nature the administration has for its employees. I really regret having left Ringling, you never know how good you had it till you are gone.
cons: There were not enough professional development opportunities in the department I worked for and it was a bit dysfunctional, not that it ever affected the student experience, but promotions and advancement were nearly nonexistent. Unfortunately, Ringling has lost some very dedicated employees within the last two years and while employee turnover can often be a good thing, the loss of experienced staff is a real problem for them currently.

review_title: Underqualified Institutional Technology Staff with a Dogmatic Work Culture
job_title: Institutional Technology Worker in Sarasota, FL
pros: They hire many student workers, and they are willing to hire inexperienced employees full-time who have no alternatives; not a bad job for someone just starting. As a result, the work is simplistic.
cons: The pay is low, and you are expected to work holiday hours and weird hours with little-to-no advanced notice or overtime compensation. While the senior management is respectful, I saw them practice numerous deceptive managerial practices especially with regards to recruitment, dismissal, and everything in between. It is not uncommon for them to let go of talented hires because they dislike ambitious people. They will spend months chasing unimportant problems and only do the minimum necessary to fix essential problems even if it has shoddy results. Additionally, most of my coworkers were appallingly underqualified and often lacked formal training or education in the technology field. There is very little chance for advancement, and the work culture is generally lazy and sterile. It's a very 'keep quiet and keep your head down' place to work.

pros:
* Opportunities to make professional connections with your fellow staffers while you develop skills that can easily be used at any job position.
* There is a lot of creative freedom with your monthly programs, use them as a chance to get to know your residents better and to take a break from classwork.
* Lots of snacks! The Residence Life office usually got the leftovers from meetings or programs and the supply closet was always well stocked (just be sure to clean up after yourself).
cons:
* You work a lot of hours (weekly office hours, on top of monthly programs, plus rounds) which will cut into the time you have to work on classwork.
* Emergencies can and will happen, they can be very stressful but you have Residence Life and Public Safety to support you.
* All the duty phone ringtones are horrible.

review_title: If you don't like being paid a living wage, Ringling is the place for you!
pros:
Benefits paid by company (for employee), those with families pay a lot for coverage
Paid vacation time - 2 weeks + for new employees up to a max of 5 for those with years of service
Holidays closed (including christmas break)
Summer hours for staff - faculty only work 10 months.
cons: Pay is on the lowest end of the scale for staff.  Increases are minimal and opportunity for growth is completely stagnant.  For an institute of higher education, Ringling does a terrible job of fostering growth amongst employees-unless you are a faculty member.  There is no consequence for bad behavior or bad management, resulting in dissatisfied employees.

pros: This job provided a lot of great travel opportunities. The students were wonderful to work with and the campus is beautiful. During the summer you work shorter hours which is great, and the insurance is amazing.
cons: Very low salary for employees who aren't supervisors, myself and another counselor worked two jobs in order to pay our bills. There is absolutely no room for growth, and they would rather hire from outside than promote from within. Upper leadership is content in their jobs since they have been around for so long, which shows in their behavior and attitude. Certain management has told employees that "they could hire anyone off the street to do this job", so beware that this is how they will treat you.

pros: Visionary leadership and stellar facilities make working at Ringling College a constantly evolving experience for those with drive and initiative. Being surrounded by a creative, diverse, international and wildly talented student body is an exceptional opportunity. Great benefits, beautiful surroundings and plenty of creative, brilliant people.
cons: Work-life balance is extremely inconsistent depending upon level of responsibility and manager. Career advancement is difficult due to small staff size.

review_title: Too many cooks in the kitchen, no clear goals.
pros: Good reputation of college in the community, and friendly, respectful co-workers.
cons: They don't look before they leap into something or, on the flip side, they talk a project to death.  Bureaucracy at it's worst. Too many people with oversight responsibilities who are able to stop a project in its tracks. Although everyone is respectful and pleasant, progress is sllllllooooooowwww.

pros: Good school, but its getting more and more expensive, its also a school for generalist, than people who want to be specialist. But great teachers ,very helpful and very dedicated to their jobs.
cons: Workload can be touch sometimes, since there are so many technical stuff to learn, its harder to actually have time to develop artistic and film knowledge, you pretty much have to learn those things yourself, because faculty wont really teach you those.

review_title: Student employee satisfied with work at Fitness center
job_title: Fitness Center Attendant in Sarasota, FL
pros: There are manageable hours, and the community of coworkers is really positive. Usually if you can't work your shift you can find someone to cover for you, and there are always opportunities to pick up other people's shifts if they can't work.
cons: The only real con to working at Ringling as a student is getting paid minimum wage. But it's also non-taxed, which is nice.

pros:
• Recently graduated and had worked on-campus for two years. Got basic job experience, pay, flexible hours, and was able to do homework during idle time on the job. Also able to interact with the community of students, faculty, and staff. Boss was real great to work with and we still keep in touch actually!
• I feel the school is headed in a positive direction, I enjoyed the tight-nit community that state colleges just can't provide. Professors for my major were fantastic and care about student success. Career services has an amazing amount of resources and staff. 
• Their introduction of the Collaboratory has been a huge success in giving students real-world job experience before graduating!
• My friends from other colleges complained that private universities tend to increase their tuition every year until they just can't afford it anymore. Ringling does not do this. I still paid the same amount I signed up for every semester from freshman to senior year, even though incoming freshmen paid more due to inflation. They didn't raise my tuition behind my back the longer I stayed.
• I don't regret going here. I just accepted a job offer for a multibillion dollar company just 3-4 months after graduating.
cons:
• Tuition price. The inflation is absolutely insane right now, and I think this applies across the country.
• Be prepared to work HARD in school. You will NOT have time to party. This is not a party school, this is not your 'average' college experience. Parents who are doctors complain that their kids are working harder than med school students.
• Don't get into the art field unless you're dead serious. Becoming an artist is grueling, if you want it easy, go to a regular college and don't waste your time here.
• Students are either very poor and in debt or very rich for obvious reasons.

job_title: Art Instructor in Longboat Key, FL
pros: Very relaxed environment, great opportunities to network and meet others. The place itself is beautiful, and the facilities are of good quality.
cons: It is small, however that may be a perk depending on your overall needs or wants. Most positions are not full-time, but part time. So depending on what you are looking for, you may be working only 5-10hrs a week.

pros: Passion for creative and career-oriented educational programs and bold risk-taking to further the institution. Primary focus on academic success and student-centered amenities. Great creative energy and myriad of ways to challenge yourself and take on additional responsibilities. Amazing technological resources and facilities. Diversity of thought and background is appreciated.
cons: Easy to get into a poor work-life balance situation with so much going on and limited administrative staff resources. Challenging to build consensus between long-term and newer, more innovative employees. Clear career path opportunities are not well-articulated.

pros:
My job wasn't too demanding of me
The job I had at the madeby gallery was a good part-time work-study job for a busy Computer Animation student
cons: The madeby gallery was criticized for needing to decide to either be a gift shop or gallery, but not both. It is still relatively new and needs to find the direction that works best for the company.

review_title: Great work environment, too many responsibilities
pros:
Housing and Meals fully covered
Guaranteed Housing
Great, friendly work environment
cons:
There's a lot of responsibilities associated with the RA position that often go beyond the 20 hours a week you are allowed to work. 
Too many unnecessary meetings and activities cuts into time that should be spent studying.

review_title: Student work study positions are key
job_title: Lab and Studio Monitor in Sarasota, FL
pros: Depending on what department you work for you basically have unlimited access to whatever you want or need, most if not all of the facility and staff are also eager to help.  On top of that you basically get paid to do your class work.
cons: Good luck getting time off, you're better off just not showing up if you need time off and taking some heat from students.

pros: Flexible schedule, can study during idle time, good community
cons: Minimum wage when it should be higher, some supervisors are better than others

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Sarasota, FL
pros: Campus environment and facilities are good.
cons: Computing area is run in draconian style and IT staff is patronized and taken for granted.  Strong word of caution for anyone considering to work in their central computing area.

pros: Always something new and interesting happening.  Employer pays for employee health & life insurance...family cost is minimal.  2 to 5 weeks vacation + 2 weeks off over the holidays + 3 personal days + up to 12 days sick
cons: Too much to do in time available

pros: It is one of the most convenient ways for students to work on campus and the relevant department. As a lab monitor, the tasks were very simple and anyone can do it.
cons: The work hours can get a bit stressful especially with 5-6 classes that I took. Work can get a bit boring.
